newsitem.title: MALAWI: Malawi's foreign debt increases in Q2 of 1996.
newsitem.headline: Malawi's foreign debt increases in Q2 of 1996.

text.p: Malawi's foreign debt increased to $2,133 million in the second quarter of 1996 from $2,043 million in the previous quarter, a Reserve Bank economic review said on Thursday.

The report said the increase in debt stock was mainly due to new withdrawals of $73.4 million for a Fiscal Restructuring and Deregulation Programme (FRDP), $1.4 million for the Malawi Social Action Fund (MASAF) and $0.9-million for primary education.
"Of the current debt stock 93.4 percent is owed by central government," it said.
Malawi paid more than $41 million in debt service in the same quarter under review, $1.8 million higher than the previous quarter.

"The increase in debt service is due to the repayment of $20.96 million short-term loan to Equator Bank and a debt relief of $2.6 million from the Dutch facility used to service International Bank for Reconstruction Development (IBRD) loans," the report said.
